questiontext.text:
Use a table of Laplace Transforms to find


$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{\sin\!\left(7\, t\right)\, \mathrm{e}^{- 2\, t}\} $$.


Laplace Transforms table can be found here.
Help on how to insert mathmetical expressions in your answer can be found here.

generalfeedback.text:
From the Laplace Tables,
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{sin(bt)\} =\frac{b}{s^2 + b^2} $$
According to the Shift Theorem,
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{f(t)e^{-at}\} = F(s+a) $$
If f(t) = sin(bt), we get:
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{sin(bt)e^{-at}\} =\frac{b}{{\left(a + s\right)}^2 + b^2} $$
Finaly substituting a = 2 and b = 7 we get:
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{\sin\!\left(7\, t\right)\, \mathrm{e}^{- 2\, t}\} =\frac{7}{{\left(s + 2\right)}^2 + 49} $$

questiontext.text:
Use a table of Laplace Transforms to find


$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{\cos\!\left(8\, t\right)\, \mathrm{e}^{- 5\, t}\} $$.


Laplace Transforms table can be found here.
Help on how to insert mathmetical expressions in your answer can be found here.

generalfeedback.text:
From the Laplace Tables,
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{cos(bt)\} =\frac{s}{s^2 + b^2} $$
According to the Shift Theorem,
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{f(t)e^{-at}\} = F(s+a) $$
If f(t) = cos(bt), we get:
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{cos(bt)e^{-at}\} =\frac{a + s}{{\left(a + s\right)}^2 + b^2} $$
Finaly substituting a = 5 and b = 8 we get:
$$ \small \mathscr{L}\{\cos\!\left(8\, t\right)\, \mathrm{e}^{- 5\, t}\} =\frac{s + 5}{{\left(s + 5\right)}^2 + 64} $$
